awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Scanning-Probe-Assisted Confocal Microscope for Investigating Optical and Magnetic Properties and Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description:
This instrument project is on development of a scanning-probe-assisted fluorescence microscope for simultaneous thermal, mechanical, magnetic resonance, and optical measurements of materials at variable temperatures and over micrometer and nanometer length scales. The complementary imaging techniques, integrated into a single platform with long-time, stable temperature control, enable nanoscale research that explores new materials and devices of emerging scientific and technological importance such as nanoscale sensing and information processing. As a whole, this project brings together a team of researchers with complementary expertise in sold-state physics, optics, and nano-engineering. Further, it offers students and postdoctoral researchers interdisciplinary education and the ability to interact with a wide network of collaborating research groups. These partnerships not only provide a broad dissemination platform but also allow the principal investigators to advance ongoing efforts to recruit and train students from communities under-represented in science.

Technical Description:
At the heart of this instrument is a closed-cycle cryo-workstation for variable temperature operation (4 K to 350 K) via contact to a thermal plate designed to minimize vibrations from a cryo-pump. A set of precision stages allows users to control the relative positions of the excitation laser beam, the scanning probe, and the sample. A miniature electromagnet is used to create a magnetic field of variable amplitude and direction, whereas a flat, glass-imprinted wave-guide serves as the source of resonant microwave and/or radio-frequency. The areas of research benefiting from this instrument include (i) the investigation of single photon emitters using two-dimensional semiconductors, (ii) the study of carrier spin dynamics in diamond, (iii) the development of new protocols for magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy at the nanoscale, (iv) the characterization and control of phase-change materials, (v) the investigation of magneto-plasmonic and spin-wave effects in magnetic nanostructures, and (vi) the understanding of single-photon dynamics in topological photonic metamaterials.

por.por_cntn:
The understanding of physics and physico-chemical phenomena in condensed matter systems largely relies on our ability to reconstruct high-resolution images with different types of contrast and hence carrying different types of information. The present project contributed to this broad area through the development of a new imaging platform in the form of a variable-temperature, spin-probe-enabled scanning microscope. This instrument articulates fluorescence microscopy, atomic force, and optically-detected magnetic resonance techniques into a single, integrated platform for nanoscale research. The central component is a closed-cycle cryo- workstation for variable temperature operation via contact to a thermal plate, in turn controlled by a "high- inertia/low-acceleration" mechanism designed to damp down the amplitude of vibrations to sub-nanometer levels.

With only few similar instruments worldwide, this system is assisting in keeping the nation's leadership in the characterization of solid state materials. Key to the system's value is its broad applicability to problems in condensed matter physics, optics, and materials sciences thanks to the unusual integration of complementary microscopy techniques. The bullet points below highlight some salient features of the system:

  • The combined use of magnetic resonance, optical detection, and atomic force microscopy sets the stage for a new form of scanning imaging that simultaneously benefits from the advantages of all three techniques, namely, high-spatial resolution, enhanced sensitivity, and outstanding versatility.
  • The use of a closed-cycle cryo-workstation allows for the continued use of the instrument at variable temperatures down to 5K. Correspondingly, this system gives the user access to virtually unlimited observation windows, a regime otherwise difficult to attain in flow cryostats (helium is a non-renewable consumable experiencing increasing costs).
  • Fully automated and remote operation is possible through an open-access, control software developed in house. Unlike commercial systems (typically featuring built-in control codes opaque to the user), this capability allows the experimenter to adapt the measurement protocol to the problem at hand, hence augmenting the range of problems that can be tackled.
  • Initial experimental work has demonstrated applications to the investigation of 2D materials and high-critical-temperature superconductors. This system, however, is poised to have a broad impact in the investigation of various materials platforms, which, besides those already mentioned, also include organic and inorganic semiconductors, various mesostructured/ mesoporous/multi-crystalline solid films, soft condensed matter and biological systems, as well as battery materials and other energy-relevant systems.

Overall, the work connected to this project led to three published scientific articles and one in preparation. It also served to train one graduate student and several undergraduates, most of them belonging to groups under-represented in the sciences. Five postdocs contributed at different stages; two of them continue working with the PI while the other three have moved on to positions in academia, national laboratories, and industry.
